markdown: <::logo: KAUAI ROSITA'S KAUAI ROSITA'S The logo features two lines of text, "KAUAI" above "ROSITA'S", both in bold serif fonts, with horizontal lines framing and separating them, and three short horizontal bars on either side of "KAUAI".::> Featuring Margaritas By The Pitcher <::illustration of cacti : figure::> 11a.m. - 11p.m. Kauai's only authentic **Mexican Restaurant** In the Menehune Village across from the Kauai Surf Hotel in Nawiliwili <::logo: POLYNESIAN SHOW POLYNESIAN SHOW The text is in a bold, stylized, rounded font, in dark gray against a light gray textured background.::> FEATURING ALL THE DANCES AND MUSIC OF THE PACIFIC! Nightly Dinner Show at 7 pm Dinner served from 6 pm to 8:30 pm KAUAI RESORT HOTEL 3-5920 Kuhio Hwy. / Phone 245-3931 Where The Wailua River Meets The Sea Hawaiian Designed NEEDLEPOINT OUR CATALOG HAS OVER 100 ORIGINAL HAWAIIAN-STYLE KITS <::Stylized breadfruit (Ulu) design : figure::> Breadfruit (Ulu) design Kit $4.50 includes mail- ing and catalog catalog only: Send $1.00 to: The Station P.O. Box 67, Hanapepe, Kauai, HI 96716 And, stop and see us on your way to Waimea Canyon! Phone 335-5731 "A most unique gift shop." RENT-A-JEEP EXPLORE KAUAI & MAUI * 1978 CJ-5. 4 Wheel Drive Jeeps. * 5-6 Passengers. * CB Radio Equipped. * Free Jeep Trail Maps. $60 per 24 hr. day No Mileage Charge Look for Airport Reservation Hotline KAUAI 245-9622 MAUI 877-6626 Mastercharge Visa American Express <::An illustration of a jeep with several people in it, driving on a road.: figure::> * $5 DISCOUNT by mentioning Ad A Gem of a Showplace (Continued from page 29) ture and stained glass enrich a gallery of the Middle Ages and early Renaissance. Adjoining is the highly valued Samuel H. Kress Foundation Collection of Italian Renaissance paintings. A series of galleries is devoted to European and American art of the 16th-19th centuries by such masters as Reynolds, Delacroix, Stuart, Homer, Peale and Copley. Hawaii- inspired art by Choris and Dampier has a logical place. Separate sections are arranged with vintage furniture, silver- ware and china. You see treasures of pre-Biblical age in a corridor of Mediterranean art. The museums's dramatic contemporary collection is housed in the wing gallery, while in the intimate Academy Theatre downstairs lectures, films and special events are presented. When the wing was opened a gallery for Arts of the Pacific, Africa and the Americas, includ- ing Hawaiian Island arts and crafts, was established off Kinau Court. The u-shaped upper floor of the Academy proper is used for changing Academy proper is used for changing <::A black and white photograph of a furnished room. In the foreground, a round wooden table with a tea set on it is placed on an ornate rug. To the left of the table, there is a wingback armchair, and further back, a wooden chest of drawers with a large ornate mirror above it. To the right of the table, another armchair is visible. In the background, against the white walls, there are several framed paintings and a tall wooden display cabinet filled with items. A chandelier hangs from the ceiling. Other smaller tables and chairs are also present in the room. : figure::> Above: English painting and decorative arts, 18th century. Below: Sculpture garden, paved area. <::A black and white photograph shows an outdoor scene with two sculptures. On the left, a dark, abstract sculpture rests on a tall, cylindrical pedestal. On the right, another dark, abstract sculpture is placed on a lower, rectangular base. In the background, there are several trees with lush foliage, and part of a building with a white roof is visible on the far left. A light-colored fence runs across the middle ground. The ground is a light, textured surface, possibly gravel or concrete.: figure::> exhibitions through the year. Late 1978 showings include Tsutsumu — The Art of the Japanese Package, jointly organized by Japan House and the American Federation of Arts, Septem- ber 24-November 5, and Art Hawaii, the Academy's 28th annual exhibition honoring island artists, through December. One section contains the Ukiyo-e Center, a showcase for the James A. Michener Collection of Japanese wood- block prints. Ukiyo-e, (floating world pictures) is an esteemed and influential genre art practiced by many true masters for 250 years. With all these attributes it is fitting that the Honolulu Academy of Arts is a Registered National Historic Place. And one final item: It's all free to the public. Hours are Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday 10a.m. — 4:30p.m.; Thurs- day 11 a.m. — 4:30 p.m., 7—9 p.m. and Sunday 2 — 5 p.m. ❀ 38 Latitude 20/November 1978

A Gem of a Showplace
(Continued from page 29)

ture and stained glass enrich a gallery of the Middle Ages and early Renaissance. Adjoining is the highly valued Samuel H. Kress Foundation Collection of Italian Renaissance paintings. A series of galleries is devoted to European and American art of the 16th-19th centuries by such masters as Reynolds, Delacroix, Stuart, Homer, Peale and Copley. Hawaii- inspired art by Choris and Dampier has a logical place. Separate sections are arranged with vintage furniture, silver- ware and china.

You see treasures of pre-Biblical age in a corridor of Mediterranean art. The museums's dramatic contemporary collection is housed in the wing gallery, while in the intimate Academy Theatre downstairs lectures, films and special events are presented. When the wing was opened a gallery for Arts of the Pacific, Africa and the Americas, includ- ing Hawaiian Island arts and crafts, was established off Kinau Court. The u-shaped upper floor of the Academy proper is used for changing
Academy proper is used for changing

<::A black and white photograph of a furnished room. In the foreground, a round wooden table with a tea set on it is placed on an ornate rug. To the left of the table, there is a wingback armchair, and further back, a wooden chest of drawers with a large ornate mirror above it. To the right of the table, another armchair is visible. In the background, against the white walls, there are several framed paintings and a tall wooden display cabinet filled with items. A chandelier hangs from the ceiling. Other smaller tables and chairs are also present in the room. : figure::>
Above: English painting and decorative arts, 18th century. Below: Sculpture garden, paved area.

<::A black and white photograph shows an outdoor scene with two sculptures. On the left, a dark, abstract sculpture rests on a tall, cylindrical pedestal. On the right, another dark, abstract sculpture is placed on a lower, rectangular base. In the background, there are several trees with lush foliage, and part of a building with a white roof is visible on the far left. A light-colored fence runs across the middle ground. The ground is a light, textured surface, possibly gravel or concrete.: figure::>

exhibitions through the year. Late 1978 showings include Tsutsumu — The Art of the Japanese Package, jointly organized by Japan House and the American Federation of Arts, Septem- ber 24-November 5, and Art Hawaii, the Academy's 28th annual exhibition honoring island artists, through December.

One section contains the Ukiyo-e Center, a showcase for the James A. Michener Collection of Japanese wood- block prints. Ukiyo-e, (floating world pictures) is an esteemed and influential genre art practiced by many true masters for 250 years.

With all these attributes it is fitting that the Honolulu Academy of Arts is a Registered National Historic Place. And one final item: It's all free to the public. Hours are Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday 10a.m. — 4:30p.m.; Thurs- day 11 a.m. — 4:30 p.m., 7—9 p.m. and Sunday 2 — 5 p.m. ❀
Latitude 20/November 1978
